caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 17.
Iphinoe africana Zimmer, 1908
, adult male. Pereopod 2.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Specimens belong to
Iphinoe africana
constituted about 30 % of the collected material. The differentiation from the very similar species
Iphinoe brevipes
Hansen, 1895
and
Iphinoe stebbingi
Jones, 1956
was discussed in this
africana – brevipes – stebbingi
group (
Jones, 1956
, Day 1978 ;
Mühlenhardt-Siegel, 1996
). We observed considerable variations in our individuals associated with growth and sexual dimorphism for several features. Concretely, the lengths of the different articles of pereopod 1 and pereopod 2 and numbers of teeth on telsonic somite. The ratio of carapace length to carapace height ranged from 2.25 to 2.75 , the basis of pereopod 1 could be longer than the rest of the limb and the basis of pereopod 2 could be nearly as long as broad (
Fig. 17
). According to Day ( 1978 ) the distribution of
I. brevipes
is limited from North to 5 °S and
I. stebbingi
is found in South Africa .
Distribution. South West Africa from Angola to Cape Point ( South Africa ), 0–130 m
